Title.evidence: Immediate vs. Early Urinary Catheter Removal after Radical Gastrectomy: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: adult patients undergoing radical gastrectomy were randomised 1:1 to IR or ER groups

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adult patients scheduled for elective laparoscopic radical gastrectomy. Exclusions were based on urogenital history or medication affecting urination.

Intervention.evidence: In the IR group, catheters were removed immediately post-surgery, while in the ER group, removal occurred within 24 hours.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the feasibility of immediate removal (IR) versus early removal (ER) of urinary catheters following radical gastrectomy under enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) protocols.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative urinary retention (POUR) with a non-inferiority margin of 10%.

Blinding.evidence: neither investigators nor patients were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: Recruitment occurred from December 2021 to June 2024.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 92 in the IR group and 89 in the ER group were analysed using intention-to-treat analysis

Result_Outcome.evidence: POUR incidence was 4.4% in the IR group and 3.4% in the ER group (P = 0.733; 1.0% difference, 95% CI −4.6 to 6.6%).

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered under NCT06718114.

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by the Affiliated Hospital of Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine.
